title: Domain 3.2: Given a scneario, install the appropriate RAM.
content:
🧠 RAM Types

📁 Virtual RAM

Not physical RAM — it's a section of your hard drive/SSD used as memory when real RAM runs out.
Known as the page file in Windows or swap space in Linux.

🧠 Tip: Slower than actual RAM. Used under memory pressure, but shouldn't be relied on long-term.

📏 SODIMM (Small Outline DIMM)

Smaller RAM sticks used in laptops and compact PCs.
Shorter and fewer pins than desktop DIMMs.

🧠 Tip: Desktop = DIMM, Laptop = SODIMM.

💾 DDR3 / DDR4 / DDR5

Double Data Rate memory — transfers data on both edges of the clock cycle.

  • DDR3: Older, up to ~2133 MHz
  • DDR4: Common today, ~2133–3200+ MHz
  • DDR5: Newest, faster, more efficient

🧠 Tip: Not backward compatible — each generation needs a matching motherboard.

🛡️ ECC (Error Correction Code) RAM

Includes extra bits to detect and fix memory errors. Used in servers and critical systems.

🧠 Tip: ECC is slower and pricier, and usually won’t work in regular consumer motherboards.

🔀 RAM Channel Configurations

Single-Channel

One stick of RAM — functional but slower.

Dual-Channel

Two sticks installed in matching paired slots (color-coded). Doubles data path and improves performance.

🧠 Tip: Always check the motherboard manual for correct slot configuration.

Triple-Channel

Seen on some older Intel platforms. Needs 3 matching sticks in the right configuration.

Quad-Channel

Used in high-end desktops and workstations. Offers peak bandwidth with 4 identical modules.

🧠 Tip: Channel setup affects performance more than just raw RAM speed.
